page.title: 12The Jersey Cow
page.content: The Jersey cow is coloured mainly fern brown and white and has an average weight of 390kg and is about 120cm high. A cow can produce ten times its own body weight in milk annually. The breed is thought to have originated in France. Jersey cows tend to live longer than other breeds. The cows are fed on nuts, bran and water during the milking period. During 24 hours about 470 gallons is collected from 30 milking cows. The milk is kept in a cooler and must stay at 5 degrees C. During the morning the Jersey milk tanker arrives to collect the milk. It is taken to the dairy at Five Oaks where it is checked for purity and what is not required as milk is made into yogurt, butter, cream or ice cream. The milk is put into waxed paper containers and distributed to shops and houses.
